title: Getting started
text: Install package r-universe follows. source code available GitHub. Load package R session installation:
code: # Install slrcsap in R: install.packages('slrcsap', repos = c('https://tbep-tech.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org')) library(slrcsap)

title: Getting started
text: package includes two core functions download data two core functions plot data. two download functions get_sealevel() get_scenario() download tidal gauge data sea level rise scenario data, respectively. corresponding plot functions view data retrieved download functions plot_sealevel() plot_scenario(). content demonstrates use function, including optional arguments can used customize output.

title: Getting started
text: Sea level data downloaded NOAA Tides Currents website. data available NOAA tide gauges setup download data St. Petersburg, FL gauge (NOAA ID 8726520) default. data read directly R URL https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/data/8726520_meantrend.txt. data includes monthly mean sea level (MSL) values 1947 present, including seasonal correction. Data alternative stations can obtained using gauge argument. sea level data can plotted using plot_sealevel() function.   Various arguments plot_sealevel() can change appearance plot. , color, units, x-axis range modified  plot also ggplot() object can modified additional ggplot2 functions. , plot modified add title change theme.
code: # Download sea level data for St. Petersburg spsealevel <- get_sealevel() head(spsealevel) #>     gauge Year Month  msl_m       date     msl_ft #> 1 8726520 1947     1 -0.063 1947-01-01 -0.2066929 #> 2 8726520 1947     2 -0.132 1947-02-01 -0.4330709 #> 3 8726520 1947     3 -0.142 1947-03-01 -0.4658793 #> 4 8726520 1947     4 -0.150 1947-04-01 -0.4921260 #> 5 8726520 1947     5 -0.086 1947-05-01 -0.2821522 #> 6 8726520 1947     6 -0.064 1947-06-01 -0.2099738 # Download sea level data for Cedar Key cksealevel <- get_sealevel(gauge = 8727520) head(cksealevel) #>     gauge Year Month  msl_m       date     msl_ft #> 1 8727520 1914     4 -0.170 1914-04-01 -0.5577428 #> 2 8727520 1914     5 -0.161 1914-05-01 -0.5282152 #> 3 8727520 1914     6 -0.142 1914-06-01 -0.4658793 #> 4 8727520 1914     7 -0.129 1914-07-01 -0.4232284 #> 5 8727520 1914     8 -0.098 1914-08-01 -0.3215223 #> 6 8727520 1914     9 -0.186 1914-09-01 -0.6102362 # Plot sea level data for St. Petersburg plot_sealevel(spsealevel) # Plot sea level data for Cedar Key plot_sealevel(cksealevel) # Change arguments for the plot plot_sealevel(spsealevel, col = 'tomato1', units = 'm',                xrng = as.Date(c('2000-01-01', '2023-01-01'))) # Add a title and change the theme library(ggplot2) plot_sealevel(spsealevel) +   ggtitle('Monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) at St. Petersburg, FL') +   theme_grey()

title: Getting started
text: Sea level rise scenarios can downloaded using get_scenario() function. Data downloaded Interagency Sea Level Rise Scenario Tool website. Details methods used tool found technical report [1]. data downloaded Excel sheet URL https://sealevel.nasa.gov/task-force-scenario-tool?psmsl_id=520, set St. Petersburg, FL default using regionally corrected NOAA 2022 curves. Emissions scenarios NOAA Intermediate Low, Intermediate, Intermediate High downloaded default, recommended Climate Science Advisory Panel. data show relative sea level change (RSLC) 2020 2100 scenario meters feet. Data alternative locations scenarios can obtained using id scenario arguments, respectively. sea level rise scenarios can plotted using plot_scenario() function.   Various arguments plot_sealevel() can change appearance plot. , color ramp, units, x-axis range modified  plot also ggplot object can modified additional ggplot2 functions. , plot modified add title, subtitle, change theme.
code: # Download sea level rise scenarios for St. Petersburg spscenario <- get_scenario() head(spscenario) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id scenario               year slr_m slr_ft #>   <dbl> <fct>                 <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2020 0.113  0.372 #> 2   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2030 0.180  0.592 #> 3   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2040 0.250  0.821 #> 4   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2050 0.322  1.06  #> 5   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2060 0.392  1.29  #> 6   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2070 0.463  1.52 # Download sea level rise scenarios for Cedar Key ckscenario <- get_scenario(id = 428, scenario = c('Low', 'IntLow', 'Int', 'IntHigh', 'High')) head(ckscenario) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id scenario  year slr_m slr_ft #>   <dbl> <fct>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1   428 NOAA Low  2020 0.101  0.332 #> 2   428 NOAA Low  2030 0.153  0.502 #> 3   428 NOAA Low  2040 0.207  0.679 #> 4   428 NOAA Low  2050 0.258  0.847 #> 5   428 NOAA Low  2060 0.301  0.988 #> 6   428 NOAA Low  2070 0.340  1.12 # Plot sea level rise scenarios for St. Petersburg plot_scenario(spscenario) # Plot sea level rise scenarios for Cedar Key plot_scenario(ckscenario) # Change arguments for the plot plot_scenario(spscenario, cols = c('green', 'blue', 'red'), units = 'm',                xrng = c(2020, 2150)) # Add a title, subtitle and change the theme plot_scenario(spscenario) +   labs(     title = 'Relative Sea Level Change Predictions',     subtitle = 'Gauge 8726520, St. Petersburg, FL'   ) +   theme_grey() +    theme(legend.position = 'bottom')

title: Authors and Citation
text: Marcus Beck. Author, maintainer.

title: Lightweight Tools to Create Sea Level Rise Predictions for the Tampa Bay Region
text: Install package r-universe follows. source code available GitHub. Load package R session installation:
code: # Install slrcsap in R: install.packages('slrcsap', repos = c('https://tbep-tech.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org')) library(slrcsap)

what: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
code: get_scenario(   id = 520,   scenario = c("IntLow", "Int", "IntHigh"),   method = "curl",   quiet = TRUE )

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: id numeric, gauge number. Default 520 (St. Petersburg, FL). scenario character, SLR scenario. Default 'IntLow', 'Int', 'IntHigh' (NOAA Intermediate Low, Intermediate, Intermediate High). See details available options. method character, download method. Default 'curl', passed download.file(). quiet logical, suppress download messages. Default TRUE.

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: data frame columns id, scenario, year, SLR meters, SLR feet.

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
text: Information https://sealevel.nasa.gov/task-force-scenario-tool?psmsl_id={gauge}. Results SLR meters feet intermediate low, intermediate, intermediate high scenarios default based recommended scenarios Climate Science Advisory Panel.  Full options scenarios 'Low', 'IntLow', 'Int', 'IntHigh', 'High'. Values SLR relative change 2020.

title: Get Sea Level Rise (SLR) scenario — get_scenario
code: dat <- get_scenario() head(dat) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id scenario               year slr_m slr_ft #>   <dbl> <fct>                 <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2020 0.113  0.372 #> 2   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2030 0.180  0.592 #> 3   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2040 0.250  0.821 #> 4   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2050 0.322  1.06  #> 5   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2060 0.392  1.29  #> 6   520 NOAA Intermediate Low  2070 0.463  1.52

what: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
title: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
text: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data selected gauge

title: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
text: gauge numeric, gauge number. Default 8726520 (St. Petersburg, FL).

title: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
text: data frame columns gauge, year, month, date, MSL meters, MSL feet.

title: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel
text: Information https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov using URL https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/data/{gauge}_meantrend.txt.  Results monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) meters feet, seasonal cycle removed.

title: Get monthly Mean Sea Level (MSL) data for selected gauge — get_sealevel

what: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
text: Plot sea level scenario data

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
code: plot_scenario(   dat,   cols = c("deepskyblue", "orange", "red"),   units = "ft",   linewidth = 1,   caption = TRUE,   xrng = c(2020, 2100),   xbrk = 10,   yrng = NULL,   ybrk = 7 )

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
text: dat Input data get_scenario(). cols character, color palette lines. Default c('deepskyblue', 'orange', 'red'). units character, units y-axis. Default 'ft'. Options 'ft' 'm'. linewidth numeric, line width. Default 1. caption logical, add caption source. Default TRUE. xrng numeric, x-axis range. Default c(2020, 2100). xbrk numeric, number x-axis breaks. Default 10. yrng numeric, y-axis range two values. Default NULL, uses range data.. ybrk numeric, number y-axis breaks. Default 7.

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
text: ggplot object

title: Plot sea level scenario data — plot_scenario
Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
text: Plot sea level data

title: Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
code: plot_sealevel(   dat,   col = "deepskyblue",   units = "ft",   caption = TRUE,   xrng = NULL,   xbrk = 10,   yrng = NULL,   ybrk = 5 )

title: Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
text: dat Input data get_sealevel(). col character, color line. Default 'deepskyblue'. units character, units y-axis. Default 'ft'. Options 'ft' 'm'. caption logical, add caption source. Default TRUE. xrng Date, x-axis range two values. Default NULL, uses range data. xbrk numeric, number x-axis breaks. Default 10. yrng numeric, y-axis range two values. Default NULL, uses range data. ybrk numeric, number y-axis breaks. Default 5.

title: Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
text: ggplot object

title: Plot sea level data — plot_sealevel
